ENSF 409.1: Have a deep understanding, and practical knowledge of object oriented analysis, design, and development.
ENSF 409.2: Define the concepts of object-oriented design, such as inheritance and polymorphism.
ENSF 409.3: Define the concepts of object-oriented design, such as inheritance and polymorphism.
ENSF 409.4: Apply miscellaneous programming concepts in Java, such as cloning, generic types, multi-threading, event-based programming, etc.
ENSF 409.6: Use databases to store and retrieve information.
ENSF 409.7: Use different design and development utilities and tools.

ENSF 607.1: Understand some of the advanced low-level design concepts, such as abstraction, modularity, coupling and cohesion, and usage of concepts such as inheritance, aggregation/composition, polymorphism, delegation, etc in Java
ENSF 607.2: Applying miscellaneous programming concepts in Java such as generic types, and multithreading
ENSF 607.4: Understand the elements of designing for non-functional requirements
ENSF 607.5: Have a deep understanding and practical knowledge of software architecture models and documentation.
ENSF 607.6: Have a deep understanding and practical knowledge of non-functional requirements and how to identify and include them in design of a software system.
ENSF 607.7: Know various software architectural styles and will be able to select a style fitting to a particular problem
ENSF 607.8: Be able to perform software reverse engineering by demonstrating it through their course project
ENSF 607.9: Know the concept of service-oriented and cloud-based architectures and will be able to demonstrate it by modifying architecture of a conventional software system to become cloud-based
ENSF 607.10: Have project management, and teamwork experience in working on a large-scale software project.

ENSF 619.1: Understand typical software lifecycle, and major phases of software development
ENSF 619.2: Understand some of the key operations in software engineering
ENSF 619.3: Understand fundamentals of systems analysis and software requirements analysis
ENSF 619.4: Understand details of the basic elements of software design: abstraction
ENSF 619.5: Understand and apply principles of modelling techniques such as UML, SSAD
ENSF 619.6: Understand and apply well-known software architectures and systematic methods
ENSF 619.7: Understand the concept of design patterns
ENSF 619.8: Understand the basic elements of non-functional software requirements
